During the course, the other students analyzed her piece as it progressed, gave her excellent reviews, and suggested she get it published. With 8,000 report cards as the only evidence of her writing ability apart from that one story, she asked the head teacher of her school for a year off to write her first novel. It helps Alice that her husband is the critic and editor Zachary Leader – his help in editing the novel was key. Alice says, ‘My mother-in-law thinks we’re now rival authors, but I think we complement each other. He works with what I’ve got on the page – he reads a chapter and changes the sentence structure, and if it’s not working, he suggests changing the words. My instinct is to keep on adding another scene. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor or critic.’

Text: 'To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to take part in a special race. The race would be man against car, and brother against brother. In the wild and mountainous Yorkshire Dales of northern England, Jonny and his younger brother Ali would race to the same point. Jonny would drive a car on roads, while Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. ‘I’m looking forward to it,’ Jonny said, as the brothers got ready at the start line. ‘I’ve never done anything like this before: it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views – and also it’s very cold right now, so I’ll be able to sit in the car and stay nice and warm.’ Alistair was also eager – though unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt, he was dressed in full winter cycling gear. The cold didn’t bother him. ‘To be honest,’ he said, ‘I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’s even going to make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up.’ The race started at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and was to finish at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, about 350 meters up. No problem for the car, perhaps – but with Alistair’s first couple of miles involving a 25 percent incline, the older Brownlee brother had a tough start. They barely had time for a quick handshake before they were off. As Alistair sprinted away on his bike, heading for a track going straight up the hill and then across the countryside to Fleet Moss, Jonny jumped in the car and was soon on the road. The next time the brothers would see each other would be at the finish line. The only question was, who would get there first? Jonny’s early confidence was quickly challenged. Barely 15 seconds into the drive, he faced his first obstacle. A giant tractor came out of a field and onto the road. ‘Welcome to Yorkshire,’ he complained to the cameraman in the back of his car. ‘If Alistair beats me, it’s all because of this farmer!’ After tense moments, the tractor was out of the way, and Jonny was back in control, driving into the morning mist. Alistair, meanwhile, was struggling with the slope. Barely a couple of miles in, and as his brother relaxed, he had to get off and carry his bike up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched as the Olympic champion kept a steady pace, carrying his bike. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side was open ground, and with the sun coming out, he had a chance to show his skills. Head down, feet on the pedals, Alistair was picking up speed. In the car, Jonny faced another local obstacle. The villages in this part of Yorkshire have been there since before cars were invented – and the roads that link them were not made for speed. Jonny tried to get through another very narrow corner. The car slowed to a crawl, then passed through a stream on the road. Clear of the last village, the car was on a straight race to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped through the final straight to Fleet Moss, Alistair was flying across his last field and back onto the road himself – approaching the finish from the other side. Head down, legs pumping… and then a squeal of brakes as he reached the line. And then, finally, Alistair looked up. ‘Is he here?’ he asked the waiting crowd. ‘No? Really?’ He raised his arms in victory. ‘Yes!’ Minutes later, the car pulled up and Jonny stepped out. ‘Well done,’ Jonny said with disappointment. ‘I’m gutted.’'

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at the Wimbledon tennis championships. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The trimmed grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all make you feel separated from the outside world. The quiet of Centre Court helps my game. In a tennis match, I try hard to focus only on the game and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by noise when a point ends: applause, cheers, people shouting your name. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people watching every move my opponent and I make. I am so focused that I forget there are millions watching me around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my lifelong coach, taught me from a young age that this was the most important tournament. By the time I was 14, I was telling my friends I’d play there one day and win. Before 2008, I played and lost, both times against Federer – in the final the year before, and the year before that. The 2006 defeat wasn’t so hard. I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty. Federer beat me easily, more easily than if I’d believed in myself more. But losing in 2007 left me very upset. I knew I could have done better, and it wasn’t my skill that failed me, but my mind. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and lose it. Toni, a tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me; he criticizes me even when I win. I must have been very upset because he told me not to cry, that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand, that this might have been my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete’s career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment counts, but some moments count more, and I let a big one pass in 2007. Toni couldn’t ease my sadness. Yet he was right. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I’d learned from that defeat; that my mind would not fail me this time. The best sign that my mind was ready was my belief that I would win. At dinner with family and friends the night before the final, at the house we rent when I play at Wimbledon, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t forbid them from mentioning it, but they knew I was already playing the match in my mind. From then until the start of play, that space was mine alone.'

Text: 'A young, idealistic Englishwoman arrived in Africa in April 1957. In one of her first letters home, she wrote, ‘I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood.’ She spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. Her name was Jane Goodall. In 1963, Britain’s National Geographical Society made Jane Goodall famous with articles and TV documentaries about her chimpanzee research. Her fame grew with her own writing, including award-winning children’s books and the 1971 bestseller In the Shadow of Man, translated into 47 languages. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, possibly only second to Marie Curie. Ironically, her fame might have overshadowed her real achievements. Many articles, interviews, and books tell her life story, but they often focus on her adventurous spirit or her dreams of living with wild animals, rather than her scientific work. These images can undervalue her true contributions. Based on the number of references to her research, the success of her students, and the data from her forty-year study, Jane Goodall should be seen as a leading pioneer in her field and a top zoologist. Her main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew they ate meat or used tools. We didn’t realize they shared emotions with humans or had social systems like ours. We also didn’t know that chimpanzee communities had different cultural traditions. Her book, The Chimpanzees of Gombe (1986), is the most important work in this area. Her study of wild apes in Gombe, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves, as chimpanzees are our closest relatives. Even as a child, there were signs of who Jane Goodall would become. One clear sign was in 1939, when she was five years old. One day, Jane disappeared, and the police were called. After a long search, she reappeared with straw in her hair. Her mother asked where she had been. Jane said she wanted to know how hens lay eggs, so she hid in a henhouse for five hours to find out. This curiosity can be seen as the start of her career as a biologist.'

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using different voices: a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV and cartoons, and to those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. ‘I’ve just done a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to quickly learn how to say lots of medical terms.’ Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Many actors think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,’ she says. ‘But there’s more to it. You have to make the script come alive for an audience who can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for publicity, but often they don’t get the parts because they’re used to acting with their whole bodies.’

After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning a regular acting career. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV adverts. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, amazingly, got a major part.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.’

Adult female actors often provide voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and many forms, which production companies on tight schedules prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the highlight of a job that includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner adverts. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this profession help,’ she says. ‘They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you're talking – that makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference.’

The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is essential. ‘It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that help voiceover artists put them together.’ She claims to have reached the top of her profession through persistence as much as talent. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or simply practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.’

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes a passion for human sound is important, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. ‘If I’ve been in the studio doing a particular kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,’ she says. ‘My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices.’

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a job many dream about as kids, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually choose more realistic jobs, like becoming a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles, like those in school notebooks, seems silly. Yet, some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, after a typical cartoonist’s childhood (loving comic strips, drawing for school publications, being known as ‘the kid who draws’), I studied graphic design in college. After graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons on local issues. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and in a few months, I was earning enough to support myself. 

To become a cartoonist, you don’t need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical barriers are low, but it’s still a tough job. No one should try to become a cartoonist unless they feel they can't do anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the rent and leaves time for family and hobbies. The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I’ve done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I’ve also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t turn down any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want to do. It also helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about everything.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs doing cartoons for newspapers and magazines. But those days are almost over. Today, cartooning is mostly an entrepreneurial activity – you have to create and sell your work. The more comfortable you are with this, the better you’ll do. I’ve seen cartoonists with average talent and great business skills do better than artistic geniuses with no business sense. It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried they won’t let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a little ‘c’ for ‘copyright’, put a circle around it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it’s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it goes viral online, it’s not a disaster – it can be a very lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and decided to get rid of some things. One of these was an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black, Japanese-made guitar. I usually hate throwing things away, so why did I want to throw this away? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to throw it on a pile of trash when a young man came up to me, looking confused. He asked, "You’re not just going to throw that away, are you?" I said I was, already feeling a bit of regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. We went our separate ways. In the years that followed, I often regretted my decision. Then, a few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish. The email was from someone I didn’t know, a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He said, "I’ve got your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold several times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back and used my name to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so emotional. I would have paid anything, but his price was fair. I had forgotten my dad’s habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this story! My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar in the 1970s when it was popular. I loved its calming sound, but I didn’t make much progress. So, I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn’t need to play well to be a rock star. When I got my guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I felt the need to stand up and play it with a strap over my shoulder. My fingers remembered the chords, even though I couldn’t draw them. My fingertips felt the pain of pressing the strings. The electric guitar is not really for playing alone. Now that I’m learning it again, maybe I’ll form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe we can play together. Or maybe there are others like me. We could call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!

There has been a lot of talk about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," about people who can't sleep, I felt like I was the only one warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and moods. As any person who struggles with sleep will tell you (and I spoke to many), sleep is very important for our mental, physical, and social health. It seems that those who have trouble sleeping understand best how important it is. So, it's good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about them in the conversation. We often lose dreams. When you wake up early, cutting off the last hour or two of sleep, you mainly lose REM or 'Rapid Eye Movement' sleep, which is the stage with the most dreams. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen during REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM, so someone who lives 90 years will spend six or seven years in REM. When researchers stop people from having REM sleep, they have more and stronger REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This suggests that dreams are important. When researchers found REM in 1953, many agreed with the famous psychologist Sigmund Freud, who said that understanding dreams was the best way to understand our minds. But it wasn't that simple. Later research on the brain didn't support this idea. The study of dreams shifted to looking at their physical origins instead of psychological ones. Currently, there is not much agreement among dream researchers, says Harvard University sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study that found actors, writers, and directors are better at remembering and using dreams than people at his sleep center. He concluded that people use dreams more if they are interested in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are creative people the only ones who can use their dreams? Doesn't everyone – like teachers, software designers, and politicians – need to think creatively? Dreams, Stickgold says, help us connect things in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new ideas. Dreams might help us see new patterns and create combinations that break our usual ways of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken up from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They 'ignore the obvious and put together things that make a kind of unexpected sense ... This is what creativity is,' says Stickgold. I write better when I wake up from intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, even one you can barely remember, seems to help with thinking. On those days, words and images come so quickly that my fingers can barely keep up. I don't know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world. We all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly as we deal with relationships with colleagues, co-workers, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England twenty years ago. In her studio, which has a beautiful sea view, there are empty frames on the walls and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a leading artist in the copyist art movement, known for her ability to recreate the richness of early-20th century impressionist paintings and the brilliance of 16th-century Caravaggio portraits. Despite her talent, she doesn't keep her own work because they are in high demand. Over her 30-year career, she has copied works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that even art experts can mistake them for the originals. While the originals are worth millions, her copies sell for between a few hundred pounds and £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them. Susie’s clients include galleries and private collectors, but she keeps their names private. Some collectors use her copies to save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank safe. Susie is honest about her work and always signs her name on the back of the canvas. She knows that selling a copy as an original is illegal and has never been tempted to do so. Although she has faced financial struggles, her situation is more stable now, and she values her reputation. Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, which paid very little but taught her accuracy. She advises young artists to learn to draw well and to study hard. Susie specializes in French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. She believes that modern art, like impressionism, is more challenging than it seems because it requires both speed and precision. Although Susie has tried creating her own art, she prefers copying because it suits her perfectionist nature.

During her racing days, nothing was more important to Ellen MacArthur than the sea, except maybe being the fastest on it. She was obsessed with sailing since she was a child. She felt a special connection with the boats that took her around the world. They worked together as one. When she returned to land, everyday life seemed unimportant, and people asked too many questions about the race. She quickly wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging herself against nature, even in dangerous places. After she came second in the Vendée Globe, a non-stop, solo round-the-world race, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was her home and workplace for 94 days. She explained how she carefully planned everything, even the number of kitchen paper rolls she needed. Preparation was crucial, she said. She proudly showed her stock of freeze-dried food, the small gas stove, and the neatly organized medical supplies. The boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, she sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. She realized things she hadn't thought about before. Seeing abandoned whaling stations made her think about how humans take what they want and move on. When I visited Ellen’s office, she was finishing a conference call. She explained why we must act now to save the planet. "No one is making more coal, oil, or gas. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find a way not to use them up." At first, her message was to use less, but then she saw things differently. Now she talks about re-using, like reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the last three years, she has visited factories, mines, and power stations, speaking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. "I will never be an expert," she says, "but I love learning. The current situation is something I can't ignore. Sailing seemed selfish compared to this. This is about finding how my voice can be most useful. It really matters."

She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and education to help young people rethink and redesign a sustainable future. "I do miss the adventure of being at sea," she says. "It is part of who I am. You are connected to everything around you. You don't have time to feel lonely. You focus on the record, on practical things, on survival. My new message is not as simple as saying, 'I’m going to be the fastest person around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this is more important than anything I've ever done."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan hopes to inspire them to go outside and try new things. His climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves ‘Team Romero’. Climbing Everest is just one part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they are thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.

I talked to some experienced Everest climbers, and none of them thought it was a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the world’s highest mountain. They agreed that a young climber might be physically strong enough, but they were not sure if a teenager would be emotionally ready. They also doubted that a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, ‘I know people criticize us, but I can’t focus on that – there’s still a lot to do. Karen and I think about the risks all the time, but we believe our experience as climbers will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He’s becoming strong and mature.’

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it just his father pushing him too far? Paul says, ‘This isn’t about me trying to be famous because of my son. At first, Jordan talked about doing this later, but we thought: ‘Why not now?’ We regularly check with him to make sure he still wants to do it.’ When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, ‘I just focus on achieving my goal.’

In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting challenge. The more exciting the record, the more people are interested. This gives Jordan a problem. People might say that focusing on records takes away the fun, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to be in the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He has to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. ‘And you know what?’ Paul says. ‘If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we’ll stop this project and go to the gym.’

Text: 'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, you can be pretty sure they’re not listening to classical music. Most of us can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends who Brahms was, they probably won’t know. I have just started a music degree, but the people in my course don’t know more about classical music than others our age. If you don’t know who wrote the music, you probably don’t own any recordings of it. The statistics must be sad for a lover of classical music. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music events, and the average classical recording sells only 300 copies. I still find that hard to believe. So, why has interest in this type of music, which has lasted for centuries, declined? The older generation blames our obsession with TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The simple truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the ones most likely to buy music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who go to classical music concerts, but they are a minority. Although I am a musician and play in an orchestra, I’m not a big classical music fan. I enjoy many styles, but judging by what’s on my computer, my classical music listening is probably close to that 3% figure. So why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, are difficult for us. We like to talk fast, play fast, and think fast. Also, experts say we have trouble paying attention for more than about three minutes; too short for most classical pieces, but perfect for a pop song. Pop is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. The topics of pop music are more appealing than a long classical piece with no lyrics. Classical music is powerful, but not full of the issues that concern teenagers. The way we listen to music has also changed. In the past, families would gather at home to make music together, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music you want online, but the soundtrack to our lives is rarely classical. When did you last go into a shop that had classical music playing? One of my teachers says that audiences at classical concerts have increased recently. Maybe, but I bet not many of those new audience members are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but no matter how cool the posters are, I see mostly grey hair in the crowd. I don’t know why people like classical concerts more in middle age, but I do know that if you’re a teenager and your parents love something, you’ll probably try to avoid it. Some say the lack of interest in classical music among teenagers is the fault of our schools, but many kids are eager to play classical music in their school orchestra. They arrive early to practice and stay after school to rehearse. Classical music appeals to them when they perform, but otherwise, it is not their music of choice. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, it’s always pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here," she said to herself. Her mother was getting out of the other side of the car and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother already knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside; it was confusing at first. Then she saw the signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," said Bonnie, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," said her mother. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be thrown out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not get it over with?" She left the building and went towards the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, she could see that right away. Almost every stall had a horse, and she walked along, looking at each one. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony as she touched its nose. The next horse surprised her. "Aren’t you the best of the lot!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. Lively, probably, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," said Bonnie, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…" His name was Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle for you. They can’t be far." The room with the riding equipment was unlocked, to Bonnie’s delight. Focused on putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I mean it, because I know about horses, even if I don’t know about anything else." She nudged him into a walk, then a trot. "If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, and the breeze made her cheeks glow. She felt Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he’d jump well.

Cody Simpson is a 15-year-old Australian who has become famous for his music. He has released many successful songs. But how did he go from being a relaxed surfer to performing on stage for thousands of fans? Cody explains, "I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven." At that time, he was also swimming and surfing every day, which were his main interests. When he was 13, he posted some videos online of himself singing at a school concert. These videos changed his life. Fans loved them and asked for more. Cody recorded more videos at home and shared them online. The response was amazing.

Cody was also a talented swimmer, training with top coaches. But when record labels showed interest, he had to make a difficult decision: stay in Australia to continue swimming or move to the US to pursue music. Cody chose music. "It was very hard for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career," he says. He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. "It was a big surprise to most people," he recalls.

Cody moved to the US with his family, leaving one dream behind to follow another. His family stays out of the spotlight but supports him from the background. Cody believes it's important to have supportive people around you. He sometimes worries about how his decision affects his younger brother and sister, especially his eight-year-old brother who travels and studies on the road. But his family reassures him of their support.

Cody's success shows that saying "yes" to opportunities, even when they are scary, is important. "Everything happened so fast," Cody says. "Now, I visit countries I never thought I would and perform for many fans. It's a dream for many people, but I know it won't last forever."

I jumped out of bed, lifted a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river bend. A new crack in the ice shone in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the wall of sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the river ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting them into place. Last week, I worked with most of the town’s adults for long hours, showing I could do it. Not that my grandfather noticed much. With one hand still on the curtain, I looked along the half-mile of steaming black water from the wood processing factory in Milltown. With fragile ice on both sides, the dark open patch was followed by solid ice downstream. As I took off my pajamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. A boy I didn’t recognize. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf along the water warmed by the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and reached for my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for the lucky chain I keep there – a silver chain my famous grandfather once brought back from a trip to South America. Better than having a famous grandfather is having this chain, which only he, my mom, and I know about. Plus, I have the diary he kept on that journey. I keep it under my pillow and read parts of it before I fall asleep. I patted the chain again and went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex.’ Mom smiled at me as I grabbed a banana from the kitchen counter. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training session. Be careful, now.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I headed down the hallway, almost bumping into Grandpa as he stepped out of his bedroom. ‘Can’t you watch where you’re going?’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going, anyway?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ As if my wetsuit didn’t make that obvious. As if he didn’t see me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it’s getting harder. ‘What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. For a moment, his sharp words hurt like he wanted them to. But I took a deep breath and counted to three. He crossed the hall and slammed the bathroom door. Mom appeared with a sympathetic smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself at the moment,’ I finished for her. I didn’t say that he’d always been that way. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a child, he was my hero – from the time he first showed me photos of him in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, above his dusty expedition medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at and, maybe soon, my own face in National Geographic. And yet, a part of me still wants to stay devoted to him, this grumpy old man. Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his bedroom more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep it up, even on these cold days!’ I smiled back at her as I peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my expedition.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried towards the boathouse.

Text: Mum caught Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa's, but different from his usual work and not finished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. There was a river in the scene; not one she recognized, maybe not even a real one, just a fantasy river. The picture was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely visible, just a hint of green, drawing the eye into the pale waters towards a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people; it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, Jess was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded too casual, hiding her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his pictures. He just painted them and let others interpret them. Mum turned the picture over and showed Jess the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed important to her, but she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it? For him to be so specific. Maybe he'll add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't resist. It's such an unusual picture, especially with a name. You can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to everyone." "Ignoramus, he said." "… every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they'd never get any work done. And he said …" Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I hoped you might know something about this painting, since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually to say the muse wasn't kind to him that day, or he had to be nice to the muse because he had a difficult part to work on. He never suggested the muse was her. She always thought he meant a goddess, not a person. And it was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

Text: 'When I woke up this morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have cut the carpet by itself. I’m not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn’t mean to damage the carpet. I didn’t wake up thinking, ‘Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.’ It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it’s too late. This happens to me a lot. I’m very unlucky that way. I was actually trying to find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It’s really cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it. I keep my collection of shells and fossils there. Gran knew I always loved her corner cabinet. I was so excited when she gave it to me! But it is a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle, so it has to stand in a corner. I have only two corners in my bedroom because it’s the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad’s; the one at the back is my sister Angela’s; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s; and the tiny one is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room and I can have his. And when Tom goes to University, I can choose. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I’ll be in my tiny room for years. I don’t really mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cosy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran’s cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. If I could only cut a couple of centimetres off the bottom of it... That’s when I had an idea. If I couldn’t cut the cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me. He always tells us to ‘think outside the box’. And that was exactly what I was doing!'

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They secretly 'borrow' things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how everything should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' point of view, not a human one, which made filming more complicated. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so if we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to get the Borrowers' perspective. They wore out many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series was shown, the famous US film director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh so much. In the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses and said it was so scary, they didn’t have to act at all. One important thing for me, which other directors struggled with, was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit during breaks and couldn’t take the dress off because she was sewn into it every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was shot with the actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each one should look – I did 2,000 of them by the end. They weren’t accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work hard and fast – I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series was successful in showing the magic of the books.

Text: 'Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists that aren’t there. Let’s see how long it takes before the craziness starts. Because it will, you know. It always does. The fake smiles, the wannabe friends, the can-you-get-me-free-tickets-to-one-of-your-dad’s-concerts? ‘Everything’s going to be fine,’ I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone with this new school and new situation. But this is what I wanted. To get away from my old life on the road and tour tutors. So while the rest of the band is renting here during the recording, we’re staying for good. I wanted to come to this school because I want to meet real kids for a change. How about a kid with a mom who works in an office? Or a dad who cuts grass? That’d be so cool. So normal. I walk into the school’s main office. ‘Hi, I need my schedule please,’ I tell the school secretary. ‘Name?’ She looks as friendly as an ice bucket. ‘Desert McGraw.’ ‘Desirée?’ she asks, leaning closer. ‘Desert,’ I repeat. The secretary seems confused. ‘Oh,’ she says and types ‘McGraw’ on her keyboard. That’s one good thing. Few people recognize my last name because my dad only uses his stage name. ‘What grade?’ ‘Eleventh.’ ‘One second, it’s printing,’ the secretary says. Then she hands me the paper. English Literature, first period. Cool, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, second floor. I studied the map the night before, so I wouldn’t look lost. When I get to the door, I hear the teacher already calling names. ‘Aurelio Gonzalez.’ ‘Here.’ She continues while I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. Her eyes look at my normal and, I think, clever outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! ‘Nice shoes,’ she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with the tan embroidered flowers. Oh no, I knew I shouldn’t have worn these. Dead giveaway. ‘Thanks,’ I say. The teacher pauses. ‘Desert... McGraw?’ she says slowly. ‘Here.’ The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read this year, she actually gives us time to talk! All teachers should do this. ‘So why’d you move here?’ my new friend asks. Let’s see, I have lots of choices here. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras, reporters, and the red carpet? Or the real reason, according to Dad? ‘We need a change, Desert,’ he said, ‘and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.’ Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they have picked South Beach Sounds, a recording studio near the sand? ‘My dad had to relocate,’ I tell her. Yes, lies always work better. ‘What does he do?’ she asks. Oh, whatever. Everyone’s going to find out eventually, anyway. But at least I’ll have some time to pretend to be normal until they do. ‘He’s an artist,’ I say, playing with the zipper on my backpack. ‘Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.’ And she didn’t seem to care. Excellent.'

Text: 'Today, the average American teenage girl is expected to be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what being an American teenager is like now. Teenage boys and girls can't just go to school and stay unnoticed, because being average is not enough. Not being ambitious is seen as laziness. "People, often adults, forget how much pressure teenagers have these days. We have lots of homework, tests, extra activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to have a social life," says teenager Kristen Loose. Even though these stresses are normal for teenagers today, negative stereotypes about them still exist, often spread by the media. You know the stereotypes: lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers may fit these descriptions, it is not fair to say all teenagers are like this. "Many people think we spend most of our time watching TV and using our cell phones," Loose says. Loose believes this is mostly wrong. She admits to having her cellphone nearby most of the time, but not just for fun. It is not only for texting friends; it is a tool that teens use to make their lives easier. Students today are expected to have quick access to the world and be reachable at all times, which can look like a cell phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can now do their work anywhere. Instead of listening to music on the way to school, they could be listening to language lessons. Schoolwork and other activities no longer stop at the school gate but need 24-hour attention from already busy teens. Many teenagers start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often end after midnight. Their schedule is full of school, after-school activities, family duties, and homework. Then, they have to get up and do it all again the next day, with less than the recommended nine hours of sleep a night. The US National Sleep Foundation found that about 20 percent of all teens get the recommended nine hours of sleep a night. Also, 28 percent of teens said they fall asleep in school about once a week because they are so tired. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen thinks that after all her activities, she gets about 18 hours of free time a week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 is not much. Olsen rarely spends those hours on social media or TV. Instead, she focuses on volunteer work. "I think the stereotype of teenagers is that they only care about themselves and their own interests," Olsen says. Despite this image, Olsen says her favorite part of the week is volunteering. "I love helping others and look forward to making a positive impact in my school and community during the week." In 20 years, who knows what the stereotype for teenagers will be, but they will still be proving it wrong and pushing the world forward. There will be another generation of students who are changing the world, all before they finish school.'

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. This group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. It's a science project with a twist: part astronomy experiment, part adventure, which attracts teenagers. I join them one weekend in late spring. They are about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. These happen when a rock or metal piece enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it gets dark, the teenagers attach a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside is a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer. Two GPS trackers are on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by someone from a nearby state, inflates the balloon, which grows to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour trip to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he says. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it's time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chant, and the balloon rises. Some run and track it with flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There is quiet and a sense of wonder. Then the balloon disappears. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets and look at the clear sky, just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city of about 4 million people. I see a boy get into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. ‘We're the only ones talking,’ says one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispers another. A meteor crosses the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops, and the balloon expands until it pops. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely. The students will find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Getting it back isn’t easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. ‘To me, recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, who notes they've lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but to get it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or a tall tree. ‘These students are native to the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader says. ‘What seems wild to some is normal to others.’ It took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, in a waterfall. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars. It’s a bit disappointing, but it’s a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they work above mountains. And it’s another adventure story to share.

Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, didn't interest her much until she was fifteen. It happened by chance. Her younger brother was interested in dinosaurs, a common phase for kids, which she hadn't gone through. She helped him with a science project and found an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology. It amazed her, and she knew she wanted to pursue it. 

I asked her about the support she received, as Palaeontology wasn't a common career choice for young people then. She remembers meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous. She was nervous, even though he was known to be friendly. She worried he might find her annoying with her questions, but he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel comfortable.

I mentioned how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. Chloe thinks films like Jurassic Park have increased interest in dinosaurs but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She feels that palaeontologists are often shown as either eccentric geniuses or awkward geeks, which isn't accurate. Her job is varied; she digs up dinosaur bones, works in labs analyzing fossils, and writes for scientific publications. She also communicates scientific findings to the public, which she finds important, especially for young people. She believes talking about dinosaurs can inspire children to learn about science.

Chloe worked on the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, helping ensure the dinosaurs were shown accurately. She says the program attracted audiences of all ages because it showed dinosaurs in a new, realistic way, different from movies like Jurassic Park.

Chloe thinks dinosaurs fascinate us because they appeal to our sense of exploration and discovery. They remind us that there is still much to learn, and Palaeontology is like a form of time travel.

Text: 'I’m just going to say this once: when you’re traveling by car with your family, even if you’re six years old, you probably know you’re not ‘there yet,’ even as you keep asking ‘Are we there yet?’ And really, once you get there, it’s not ‘there’ anymore, is it? It’s ‘here’. So if you think you might be ‘there,’ you should ask ‘Are we here yet?’ And I’m sure no one wants to be ‘there yet’ more than the mums and dads who hear that question over and over on long car trips. I mean, seriously – what are we kids complaining about? Just think about it. Wouldn’t you rather be relaxing in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs you haven’t seen before, listen to music, or do puzzles, while the scenery goes by outside the window. In the front seat, mum or dad is there to give out juice boxes and cookies, or change the radio station and temperature – basically, to keep everything running smoothly! Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying – usually my younger brother, Tim. Like putting his foot on my side of the seat. What? He can’t do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then it’s his other foot, then a hand, and soon he’s in my space and we start fighting. The driver and co-pilot reach back to separate us as the car speeds up and swerves. They tell the younger sibling to stay in his own seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a while. And the beautiful scenery continues to pass by. Soon after, I’m trying to read, and I feel something – a breeze on my arm. But the car’s not going fast and the window’s not open. Where’s it coming from? My brother is in the next seat, quietly blowing on me. He’s on his side, not touching me – so he’s found a loophole. Just breathing? What’s wrong with that? The anger grows. Tim gets yelled at, there’s more swerving. Then slowly things calm down again – for now. Over the years, Dad has developed ways to deal with us kids in the back seat. For example, when we ask ‘Are we there yet?’ he often says, ‘Yup. We’re here. Get out of the car.’ ‘But Dad. We’re still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour.’ ‘Oh, well, then maybe we’re not there yet.’ That kept us quiet for a while. You know you’re finally ‘there’ when you see the grown-ups get out of the car and go as far away as they can from the kids who have bothered them for hours. So remember: if mum and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no. You’re not there yet.'

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope people will love the experience and come back. Zuzi explains that they wanted to create a place where people can connect without using technology. She says, "Everyone is busy with their phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together to communicate face-to-face."

The games played in their café are called 'Eurogames'. These games have gentle themes like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, now known as Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources, keeping everyone involved until the end. This idea was improved in 'co-operative' games, where players win or lose as a team, encouraging more social interaction. One popular co-operative game is Pandemic, created by North American designer Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. He remembers playing it with friends and feeling excited, whether they won or lost. This inspired him to create games that bring people together.

Leacock loved board games as a child but often felt disappointed by them. With help from his uncle, he started designing better games. Pandemic became very successful, and its follow-up version included more storytelling. Leacock says it is like an electronic game where you develop characters and the story changes.

The growth of video games has helped the success of modern board games. Video games have made playing games more normal. Ben Hogg, from a leading games company, says, "Everyone with a smartphone has at least one game they like to play." Video games used to offer social interaction in arcades or with friends at home. But now, many video games are played online, where players are not physically together. This has led some people to look for games they can play with others in person.

John and Zuzi's café shows that tabletop gaming is more than just fun. In our online world, these games offer a way to connect with others in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many false beginnings. Jamie says his mother was a great singer and she helped him start playing the guitar. The only radio station he heard at home was for middle-aged people, which influenced him as he grew up. He says he was 12 before he heard a modern song. Around that time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. "With tennis, I was quite good," he says. "But it wasn't what I wanted to do for the rest of my life. It was just too much hard work." At 17, he left school to try to become a performer. He was in a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as interested in a music career. "I went to my parents and broke down," he recalls. "I told them this is what I wanted to do, that I had been writing lyrics in economics lessons and playing the piano every day when others were outside." His dad gave him 18 months to succeed; if not, he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels only wanted him as a solo artist, so he had to leave his friend. In the end, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and switched to another label to release a new album. Fame and fortune did not come. "In my own artist career, I feel like I've been in the wrong place at the wrong time," he says. "But as a writer, I've been in the right place at the right time." Writing for others is where he truly succeeded. "I like to think I'm one of the main writers in the UK that labels send new artists to," he says. This, he believes, helps start their careers. Sometimes he explains to the artists he helps that writing with the charts in mind is okay. "Why not? Don't you want 10 million people streaming your music next month? I'm not saying they should write a bad song, but we should create something amazing that will also sell well." It's refreshing to hear someone speak honestly about wanting to write big hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he just knows he wants to write number ones and has the talent to do it. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his goal. "That's the goal when I go into the studio with someone," he says. "We need to aim for global success and write the best music of next year. It's not just about being cool. We want to write classic modern pop songs."

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very famous online, but people who don't watch online videos of bike stunts might not know him. He is a 'street trials cyclist', which means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online. When I met him for an interview at a BMX park on a Saturday morning, many local boys and older people recognized him and called him 'an absolute legend'. After seeing his skills, I agreed with them. Even though I was doubtful at first, I was impressed by his bravery and creativity. Before each stunt, he explained what he planned to do, and I often doubted he could do it. But after he succeeded, he seemed not very interested in my praise. Despite his online fame, Tony says he is a reluctant celebrity. He finds it hard to be social and prefers doing things rather than talking about them. This is interesting because his fame comes from social media and camera technology. He says this technology helps people like him make a living. However, he sometimes feels that everyone is too focused on cameras and screens. But he is not complaining because his videos allow him to earn money from what would have been just a hobby in the past. From my experience interviewing top athletes, I know that two important factors make a child into a top competitor: energy and the ability to overcome disappointment. These are more important than talent and help someone keep going despite failure. In risky sports, mental strength is very important. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on easy but new obstacles. He just got up and tried again until he succeeded. Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some people think he takes unnecessary risks. Tony says these people don't understand the sport and don't know he gets expert advice to reduce risks. He is careful about the risks he takes. He says some people never feel scared and shouldn't do these sports, while others feel fear but can overcome it. He is in the second group. He is not addicted to risk and spends a lot of time planning. Sometimes he needs time to get ready mentally before trying a new stunt. He knows he must not lose confidence before jumping. If he fully commits, he is fine.

Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous challenges for charity. She has run a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground. She walked between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her keep her balance and not fall, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen took lessons from an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found out that high-wire walking was very different. "The training was a shock," said Helen. "I didn’t realize how strong I’d need to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill; then came an hour of exercises, with another hour after my day practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could continue. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!" On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen controlled herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. "That was the scariest thing I’ve done," she said afterward. "I’m glad it’s over!" However, the experience has not stopped Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. Before this, he had written a book about his travels in Canada in a 50-year-old car. He loved motor sports and worked building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and even used it to go on holiday to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a normal touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003 due to a knee injury, he finally set out in 2006. He traveled for three years through 23 countries on four continents. The best part of the trip was arriving in Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains on their bikes, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further away from home I got, the more amazed people seemed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. A serious fever left him in a hostel bed without medicine for ten long days. He had no money for hospital bills or the journey home. Yet despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using an exciting tool called a 'night-vision scope'. This tool helps us see the ducks in the dark! We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are not sure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but nothing about their night activities because we didn't have the right equipment before. This new 'scope' gives us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about how to protect their habitat. The work is very hard. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and write down notes on every duck I see. The weather has been challenging – some nights are mild, but often it is wet. Also, it is so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. Still, I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to what summer will bring – hours in a laboratory, where we will look at our results together. It will be hard to be inside, but it is important to do this. And I wouldn't change it for anything!

Text: 'When I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it exists. But it's true! I spend my workdays eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is important to make sure customers get perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from the company I work for. Every week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate, from our factory. I check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit. I spend time choosing the best ones for the chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste products I make. I keep my colleagues happy by giving them samples! My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to experiment with. It's great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I am at our food lab, and other times I’m traveling to buy our raw materials. Since I have a young family, that can be hard. But I love the variety and lack of routine in this job, although I think the best part is still the chocolate! People often ask if I get bored of chocolate. I’ve worked with it for a long time, and I’ve never felt like I didn’t want to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more in the evening!'

Text: 'Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson is from Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. She says her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which means flying through the air above an amazed audience. In the year-long course, students slowly take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, “For a circus career, performers need to avoid doing the same thing all the time – it’s important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practising. Another great part is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important - circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get injured, or that you might only work for a short time each year. But, actually, the real issue is planning for the future because you can only travel while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many former students start businesses all over the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, however, it’s not a job for making money! “The work usually means not having a regular salary. It’s also competitive - but great fun!”'

Text: 'You may not know her name or her face, but you’ve probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She supports the lead singer by singing in the background. Many people think that backing singers aren’t good enough to be lead singers. That’s not true – they have to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! ‘What I love about my job is that when I walk into the recording studio, I never know what I’ll be asked to sing,’ she says. ‘It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I’m often surprised by producers’ requests. I was once asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue, I just do the job!’ ‘Excellent musical abilities are essential for my work, plus the ability to learn quickly. There’s often no printed music to look at. I’ll never forget my first experience of recording the background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra as well. I was terrified: I knew that if I got something wrong, it would mean recording everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough as they are.’ ‘One of my favourite jobs is doing recordings for songwriters. Less experienced writers don’t always understand which musical range suits the female voice best. By listening to me perform their song, they can figure out how to improve it.’

Julie Deane started her business with only basic knowledge of fashion. She created a successful company with her 'satchels', which are traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular with many celebrities. Before choosing to make satchels, Julie considered different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She didn't just go with her first idea. When she decided on satchels, not everyone agreed with her choice. Julie says, "Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced." She worked with her family from the beginning, especially her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels came from children's storybooks. Although Julie didn't know much about fashion blogs, they have been important to her success. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To create interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her satchels grew, as did the speed of production. Julie now enjoys seeing which celebrity is pictured with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online advertising, she uses the internet community to get ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied Julie's design to sell similar products. Because of this, she now makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices – people love working there. There is now a new factory, and while buildings are important, it's the team that makes it a special place.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. But the swimming club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to balance training with schoolwork. When they were teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky thought it looked exciting and decided to try it too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so she could easily attend training sessions after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. Then, at 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky said, ‘I loved winning competitions for years, but I started to feel tired of it – and when the excitement stops, there’s no point. Luckily, I found a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport,’ she says. ‘The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, and it brings young people together as part of a group.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘I know some people doubt if celebrity support is always good for a charity. They say celebrities only do it to promote themselves, which hides the real work of the charity.
