Journal-based peer review is the process where experts in the same field check a scientific research paper. It is seen as a way to ensure the quality of research. This process is said to stop flawed or nonsensical papers from being published. Scientists often mention it to reassure the media and the public. However, reviewing a paper can delay its publication by up to a year. Is this delay worth it to ensure trust in published research? The answer is both yes and no. 

Examining these issues shows that scientific publishing is changing. I am not ready to give up on journal-based peer review. I believe all papers should be checked before formal publication, but things are changing. The use of preprints is a big part of this change. Preprints are drafts of papers posted online without peer review. They allow new results to be shared quickly so others can read, critique, and build on them. 

Publishing in journals has become more about gaining fame and advancing careers. This has changed the motivations of authors and reviewers. Scientists compete for spots in top journals, which publish excellent research. But the high rewards for publishing in these journals can lead to cutting corners. Stories that leave out inconvenient data are more likely to be published. Reviewers now often decide if a paper is good enough for a journal, not just if it is good. For top journals, this can depend on how newsworthy a paper is, not just its scientific quality. 

These problems are known, but few people want to change the system. However, preprints might offer a solution. They do not require a big change from the current system. Preprint archives have existed for twenty years, but they are not widely used. This is partly because scientists are conservative and because many think journals will not accept papers posted as preprints. There is also a fear that publishing without peer review will lead to 'junk science,' but this has not happened yet. 

Preprints are not peer-reviewed, but authors know they will be critiqued by a global community. Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, shared her experience: ‘My paper critiqued a published paper, which is hard to do in traditional journals. With anonymous peer review, the original authors might block a critical paper. By posting a preprint, the original authors could respond, and all comments were public. This way, readers can judge the quality of the arguments. Even if journals reject our paper, the preprint and comments are still available, so our work is not wasted.’

Preprint archives allow global scientific discussions that used to be private. They can also share negative results, which journals often ignore. Preprints increase how often papers are read and cited, showing their effectiveness. By using the web’s openness, preprints focus on the work itself, not where it is published.

Text: 'When I ask my literature students what a poem is, they often say things like ‘a painting in words’. These answers usually don't satisfy me or them. One day, I asked a group to choose an object and write one paragraph describing it like a scientist would, and another from the object's point of view, calling it ‘Poem.’ Here’s what one student wrote: Poem I may look strange or scary, but I’m a device that helps people breathe. I’m only used in emergencies and even then only for a short time. Most people will never have to use me. The item? An oxygen mask – a surprising choice that helped the class see how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise led to fun and useful discussion. When I was in school, poetry often made no sense to me. I saw every poem as a confusing puzzle that blocked true understanding and feeling. After school, poetry becomes something most people care about less and less. Sometimes you see a poem, and it stands out because it is not like regular writing. It almost challenges you to read it, which you do, and often feel let down by its simplicity or because it is hard to understand at first. Still, you feel good for trying. What do we hope to find in poems? Aren’t they supposed to hold deep feelings, beautiful images, gentle thoughts, or sharp humor? The answer might seem to be yes. But if we want tears, we watch movies; for information or sharp critique, we read online articles. Novels offer us worlds to escape to, paintings give us visual pleasure, and music – well, nothing beats the mix of lyrics, instruments, and melody. However, one thing a poem can offer is ambiguity. Everyday life – unlike reading sentence by sentence – is full of it. But these ideas still don’t tell us what a poem really is. If you search online for ‘poem’, it redirects to ‘poetry': ‘a form of literary art which uses the beauty and rhythm of language like sound symbolism, etc.’ This is fine for English professors, but it hides the word’s roots. ‘Poem’ comes from the Greek poí?ma, meaning a ‘thing made,’ and a poet is ‘a maker of things.’ So if a poem is a thing made, what kind of thing is it? Poets sometimes compare poems to wild animals – untameable, unpredictable – or to machines – carefully made and precise – depending on their view. But these comparisons don’t hold up when looked at closely. The best part of trying to define a poem through comparison is not the comparison itself but the discussion it creates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change how you think about machines or wild animals. It can help the mind try new ways of thinking and make us see everyday things differently. The poem as a mental object is not hard to imagine, especially if we think about how song lyrics can get stuck in our heads. The mix of words and melody is powerful, going back to childhood rhymes like ‘Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me.’ But aren’t words sometimes like sticks and stones? Think about a poem on a page of a newspaper or magazine, looking right at you: A poem can hit home like nothing else, even though, in terms of ink on paper, it does nothing more than the prose around it. What about all that empty space around the poem – space that could have been used for a longer article or ad? A poem is made by writing and rewriting just like an article, story, or novel, yet it never really becomes what they usually are – a thing made to be sold. Publishers write press releases and send out review copies of poetry collections, but few expect a collection to pay for its printing costs. A poem presents itself not as something for the market, but as something for its own sake. Because of its special status – set apart in a magazine or book – a poem still has the power to surprise, even if only for a moment.'

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. Back then, £70 was a lot of money, and it might have been better to spend it on something useful for the house. Still, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first try. Over the years, every brooch and coin I've found has made me happy because it connects me to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years to find something else that impressed Marion as much. 

It was a dull February afternoon, and I had a couple of hours free. I had a place in mind to search, but because it was raining, I chose a closer spot that mostly had old farming tools. The first time my detector beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I tried to ignore it but couldn't leave without checking. I dug down half a meter and was lying in the mud when I saw a round, golden ball. I had found brass curtain rails before, so I tried not to get too excited. But as I cleared more dirt, the ball turned into a thick, detailed loop. I stopped and stared. Then I remembered to breathe. I had seen something like this before—the Great Torc in the British Museum. It’s the most famous object from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years old. A torc is a beautiful necklace of gold and silver, with a gold ring at each end, just like the one I found. 

I took it to the car. On the drive home, I kept looking at the torc on the seat next to me. I washed it in my kitchen sink, probably the first clean it had had since ancient times. ‘Marion!’ I shouted, ‘I've got something for you.’ Still looking at my find, I heard my wife come in and stop. ‘What is it?’ she asked. I explained it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn't try it on because we didn't want to damage it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. We had never been robbed, but I was anxious. Eventually, I got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it there. The law says such finds must be reported to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as possible before giving it up—I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone when I put the torc on his desk. He turned, still talking, then stopped mid-sentence. The torc was authenticated and eventually sold to my local council. It's now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 proceeds were split between the field's owner and me. But the torc has been more than just a lucky find. It's something I've saved for the nation. People say to me, ‘Now that you've found something so amazing, are you going to stop detecting?’ But those brooches and coins are still interesting to me. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn't stop—not while there's a chance of catching a bigger fish tomorrow.

Sleeping is one of my favorite things about traveling, but I don't talk about it much because I feel a bit guilty. When friends tell me about their busy travel plans, full of activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and listen. What would they think if they knew my travel plans include time for afternoon naps during Caribbean rain and lazy mornings in Italian beds? Better sleep is a happy part of traveling. When I visited Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept—more than 12 hours most days. There were noisy birds nearby, but it didn't bother me. Away from home, in a new place with different smells and sounds, I could sleep deeply and enjoyably. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. But I think there's more to it than just relaxing. I believe sleep is part of our travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we experience new sights, sounds, and smells. We take in new cultures, music, and landscapes. During sleep, we process all this new information. That's why sleep feels more intense when we travel. Sleep also changes with different places. People worry about jet lag, but I think adjusting to local customs is harder than adjusting to time zones. On the Caribbean island of Trinidad, people wake up early to avoid the heat, rest around 10 a.m., and become active again in the evening. Even though Trinidad is just one hour ahead of New York, where I live, it takes me days to get used to their sleep pattern. Once I do, I feel like I've truly arrived. I remember an afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a big lunch with new friends. After eating, everyone slowly stopped talking and went to rest on hammocks and sofas. I realized why there were so many pillows on the floor. I joined them and experienced the Latin American tradition of the siesta. I shared not just sleep, but a part of Dominican life. Travel sleep is also memorable. Away from my usual routine, I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds in my sleep. If 'slow travel' means enjoying every experience fully, then what is slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed and tell my friends that travel sleep is an activity too.

The woman turned away from the mirror. "What do you think? And be honest." Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a soft layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one suits you best," she said to her customer politely. The woman wrinkled her nose and frowned, looking like a bulldog. "But it is so boring," she said. "Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little beauty will make me stand out." She patted the red and black small top hat on her head. "Yes," she said firmly, "this is the one I want." Mia knew she couldn't change her mind, so she smiled and agreed that the woman would stand out at the wedding. She thought of her own daughter, Jen. It was Jen's thirtieth birthday today, and they were having a family gathering. It had been a while since everyone was together, and she looked forward to seeing Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious about the friend Jen was bringing. They knew nothing about this friend, as her husband Jeff had pointed out when Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie. "Tattie," Jeff said when Mia told him, "What kind of name is that?" "It's short for Tatiana," Mia replied. "I think it’s nice." "It sounds pretentious," Jeff retorted. Her husband disliked anything showy or fake. He also didn't believe in being too polite, which he called Mia’s reluctance to speak her mind. He wouldn’t have hesitated to tell the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat. He might have even said that a trash can lid would look better on her. "The trouble with you, Mia," he often said, "is that you’re too polite for your own good." An hour later, Mia closed the shop and entered the back door of Medlar House: her commute from work was only forty seconds. Four years ago, when Luke, their youngest child, left home, Mia had the idea to convert the unused barn next to the house into a bright space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. "Do you really think people want hats?" he asked. Mia knew from friends who struggled to find the perfect hat for special occasions that there was demand. She was right. From the start, after Jen helped her create a website for the business, Mia’s Hats was a success. Women came from far away to her showroom in the village of Little Pelham, where she offered a relaxed and welcoming environment. She let them try on as many hats as they needed to find the right one. With changing rooms available, she encouraged customers to bring their outfits so nothing was left to chance. She recently expanded her service to include handbags and costume jewelry.

Text: 'It's a long way from London to Atlanta, and in his new American home, Lawrence Okoye thinks about his amazing sports journey. He is confident, but even he is surprised by how far he has come—from an Olympic discus final to possibly joining a major USA team. Lawrence has never played American football before, but he might be picked for one of the top teams. In Atlanta, he is still learning his new position. The idea that a 21-year-old from London could be chosen for a big American sports team is surprising. But Lawrence is used to proving people wrong. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but delayed it to train for the discus, after playing rugby. Within 20 months, he was the world's fourth-best discus thrower. Lawrence went to Atlanta for warm-weather discus training, preparing for the world championships. 'Yes,' Lawrence says when asked if he is really trying for an NFL contract. 'American football was in my mind, but I decided to try it when I got to the USA. At school in London, I thought about it, but it seemed crazy then.' Soon after arriving in America, he read about NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played, did he think he could be chosen? 'Pretty much,' Lawrence says. 'I applied online.' Was he nervous being tested with experienced players? 'No,' he says. 'I don't get nervous for many things.' He doesn't talk much, but he believes in his abilities. His test results made him the most impressive player. 'I was very pleased to hear that.' It was the only time he showed pride. But he is also careful. Lawrence has no experience. How can he join an NFL team? 'Coaches say I have the right skills. It's about how hard I work,' he replies. Will he be calm while waiting to hear if he's selected? 'I will be. There's no pressure on me. People say I'll be selected, but I'm not worried.' This calmness might come from his Olympic final, where he came last. He seems to have moved on and is happy he made it to the final with a great last throw. 'That was an amazing day,' he says. 'The final didn't go as I wanted, but that's sport. I can return to it.' After the Olympics, some thought the event affected him. Lawrence doesn't comment. An NFL player's minimum salary is over $400,000 a year, so the money is a big incentive. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With his talents, should he focus on one sport? 'I understand why someone would say that,' he responds. 'I'm trying to achieve a dream I've had since school. If it doesn't work out, I can go back to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I've made has been planned.'

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see that it was already daylight. Looking out of the window, I saw the empty landscape below. The dark shades of brown and green reassured me that, although it was mid-September, it had not yet started snowing in Siberia. I could see no sign of human life, and the view stretched out in a mix of mountains, streams, and forests to an endless horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. "Good morning, Robert," he said with a slow, Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow flying to the far reaches of civilization to sell safety clothing to local mining industries. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I had explained to him that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with only a one-way ticket because I planned to return home to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he said, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I explained that I believed there was a road, though not many people used it these days. "Alone?" he asked, pointing at me. "No, I will be riding with a friend called Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I nodded. Sergei still looked unconvinced and with just one word "Holodna" (cold), he pointed outside. I tried to reassure him with hand gestures that I had a lot of warm clothes, though I left out the fact that, because my trip was self-funded, I was on a tight budget. Most of my clothes and equipment had been bought at low prices. In reality, I was not sure they would be good enough. This was especially true of my large postman’s over-trousers, which I had bought for £10. It had all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall that morning was full of students slumped in their seats. Some were taking notes without energy. The lecturer droned on. I was thinking hard about a particular dilemma. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." In the row in front of me slouched Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my messy writing, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. "OK," it said. It was six years later that I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still far from having full control of my classes, the job was good for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, often fulfilling, and, of course, there were long holidays in which to chase adventures. Twice since I had started teaching, I had used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventure bug in a big way after our bike ride through Pakistan and had decided to do something far more relaxing than teaching: to cycle around the world. Ever since that first ride we had taken together, Al had been setting himself greater and greater challenges. This round-the-world-by-bike trip was certainly his greatest so far. At times he thought that the ride, or the road, would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him in many ways. He was having an extraordinary adventure, finding that he could deal with each new challenge even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong the skeptics who had told him he could not do it. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.

Text: 'In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns to race through a series of pylons that are between 15 and 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it feels like to take part. An hour before the flight, I had to sign two forms. The first confirmed that I was in good health, and the second that I would empty all my pockets, because small objects can become dangerous during the flight. I also learned that I would need to stay oriented. ‘The horizon is your best friend,’ I was told, ‘the pilot will explain which direction to look.’ I was also asked to promise that when flying upside down, I would ‘completely relax. Try and enjoy the view.’ Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety briefing where I was told not to touch anything. By the time we were moving down the runway, my legs were up in front of me, feet trying not to touch the important steering pedals, hands trying not to rest on any of the many important switches within reach, my mind was made up. Ignoring all instructions, I would not relax and enjoy the flight. This is the challenge of high-speed acrobatic flying. To survive without passing out, you have to stay calm and focused. You have to tense up at the right time and relax at the right time. Panicking is a bad idea. None of this was comforting as we began accelerating down the runway. Dario, the pilot, and I reached the end of the runway. We were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the world’s fastest acrobatic planes, ready to go. The plane took off and two seconds later we turned sharply to the right. It was a sudden, strong move and I felt the air squeeze out of my lungs. I looked up at the horizon, tensed everything, and took short breaths as I sank into the seat. For a moment, I weighed 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out. We turned sharply left and dived, leaving my stomach at 2,000 meters and my lungs pressed against the roof of the plane. Seconds later, we were 10 meters off the ground, aiming for the small space between two pylons. They passed at 400 km per hour but my moment of excitement was interrupted by a sharp right turn. We hadn’t even done any acrobatics yet. For two minutes, I was allowed to fly the plane, my hand shaking so much the plane shook too… it’s that responsive. Then Dario said something. I asked, ‘Can you repeat that?’ But instead of replying, he did a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. ‘Are you okay?’ ‘Yup.’ ‘Have you had enough?’ ‘No,’ I lied. Then he did a loop, flying the plane up and over, making a full circle in the air. I know many people would find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters. However, I thought it was a bit much. At the top of the loop, as we were flying upside down, I heard a small voice saying, ‘Relax, relax, look up.’ Then I looked up and saw some fields. The flight was over in 10 minutes. It had been ‘soft’ compared to what the pilots endure when they race. To show this, Dario got out some sandwiches as soon as we landed and happily ate. I didn’t eat for hours and that night I dreamed of doing loops over and over again.'

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you’ve ever seen amazing footage of polar bears in a nature documentary, it was probably filmed by him. He says his perfect temperature is -18C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first passion, where he learned about surviving in cold places. His big opportunity came when a TV crew arrived in Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. ‘I ended up taking the crew to different places, and after 48 hours I realised that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, underwater.’ He is now a top cameraman and has worked on many major TV wildlife series. ‘I started at a good time. When I began, hardly anyone had been to the Antarctic. You had coral people, elephant people, chimpanzee people. I just became the cold man. It was like all these amazing scenes were just waiting to be filmed.’ The camera and communications technology was very basic when he started 35 years ago. ‘It is certainly easier to film today. If you shot something then, you had to remember it. Today, with digital technology, you can shoot a lot and look at it immediately. You used to have to think about what shots you needed next, and what you had missed. You shot less. Film was very expensive. Today you can have too much material.’ ‘My value is field experience in cold conditions. I have a feel for it. I have spent so much time on sea ice it now feels like crossing the street. I do get cold toes but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, no diseases or mosquitoes.’ Wildlife filming, Allan says, is full of great successes, but also failures and embarrassments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes. Unfortunately, he could not identify which birds they were. When Allan recently got permission to film sequences for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, he did not expect an easy task. It is a world of polar bears and is strictly off limits to all but the most fearless or foolish. Usually -32C in April, the wind is strong and carrying cameras in the deep snow is very difficult. After walking five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow slopes for 23 days, however, Allan had seen just one mother bear and her cub. By day 24, though, he says, he was living in bear world, at bear speed, with bear senses. ‘We find a new hole and wait. We shuffle, hop, bend, stretch and run to stay warm. Five hours of watching and then with no warning at all I catch a glimpse so brief that I almost miss it. But the camera’s locked on the hole on full zoom and my eye’s very quickly on the viewfinder. Nothing for a couple of seconds and then an unmistakable black nose. Nose becomes muzzle, grows bigger to become full head and in less than a minute she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She’s looking at me but she’s not bothered. I’ve just pulled out of a close-up thinking this can’t get much better … when she sets off on a long slide down the slope. I’d swear it’s partly in sheer pleasure,’ he recounts, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. ‘Clearly it’s their first view of the world … It’s show time on the slopes and we have front-row seats.’ Now Allan would like to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and experience the impact of it first hand. He says he would be able to make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting more supplies on the way. This meant swimming through very cold waters and facing frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole too. Now he is back in the Arctic, planning an even more ambitious expedition. Explorers are confident and driven people, and they need to be. This time, there is much more at risk. Pen and two colleagues will go on a three-month, 1,000-kilometre journey to the North Pole, taking detailed measurements of the ice's thickness and density. No one has done this before, and he knows the results will be very important for scientists. This will give the clearest picture yet of how global warming is affecting the polar ice. Pen was trained for this job. As a child, he was looked after by a woman who had worked for the famous polar explorer, Scott of the Antarctic. She was hired to make him tough by sending him out into blizzards and icy winds with very few clothes. His father gave him a love for frozen adventures, and Pen showed unusual physical endurance. Pen is married to Mary, a horsewoman, who says he has a ‘spine of steel’ and shares his love for the outdoors. She helps run his polar guide business and says she worries more about him when he’s at home: ‘He’s in more danger driving along the A303 because I know that in his head he’s somewhere in the Arctic.’ For fun, she once raced against him in a famous mountain event where riders on horseback compete against people on foot. Mary and her horse finished an hour before Pen. Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. ‘It’s much harder to be away from them this time,’ he admits. ‘They were one and five when I last went, and I made a mistake in how I said goodbye. I told my son, “You’re the man of the house now, look after your mum and your sister.” He took it seriously, asking his mum how she was all the time, but it became too much for him. It was well-intentioned but unfair.’ For similar reasons, he plans to have very little contact with them while in the Arctic. ‘If you call them, you remind them how far away you are.’ He is spending these last days before leaving preparing his equipment carefully. ‘Out on the ice, you can’t fix things or do anything that isn’t simple,’ he says. With him will be Ann Daniels, a leading polar explorer, and the expedition photographer, Martin Hartley. They will have a team of six flying in supplies. Being part of a team is more stressful for someone like him, says Pen, and he has something else on his mind too. ‘I’m going to be 47 on Thursday. I’ve done far less training than I’m comfortable with.’ Why? ‘Organisational things always seem more urgent. So I’m almost fearful of what I’m going to ask of myself.’ Pen believes his mission reconnects exploration with the search for knowledge that inspired past explorers. ‘Reaching the North Pole was a personal goal,’ he admits, ‘and not very useful to anyone beyond the polar adventuring community. This time, scientists will benefit from the data, and we’re creating a way to involve as many people as possible in what’s happening in the Arctic Ocean. This is important work, and only we can do it,’ he says. ‘Our skills, which are usually unusual and not needed in society, have become very relevant. Suddenly, we’re useful again.’

Text: I had a 'year off'. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is amazing. I had the chance to do more writing, TV work, and speak to businesses and schools. These activities were great, but I missed having something competitive to focus on. I wanted to stay in shape in case I wanted to compete in the Olympics again. So, I entered marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle's invitation: 'Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?' I love rowing and missed the feeling of the boat moving through the water, but I wasn't ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but no one was interested. I knew if I entered, I would want to win. Would rowing with Ben give me the best chance to win? Probably not. But being an underdog with no pressure was interesting. I contacted Ben. He was going to do the race anyway and had found the money for the entry fee and a boat deposit, making the race a real possibility. We talked about the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000 – a lot of money. We thought we had a good chance, but it would take work to secure it. Besides the race costs, I also had to consider losing money from being away from home. Speaking at business conferences is a good way to earn money as a retired athlete. It's nice that people are interested, but I find it hard to talk about past achievements without a new goal. Doing the race would mean I could talk about something new: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one big lesson was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. Preparing for the Olympics was tough, but looking back, it was straightforward. Yes, I trained almost every day, but the program was set, and there were doctors and dieticians. I was worried about what people would think of me racing with a TV presenter. I didn't want it to look like I just wanted to be on TV. My worries went away during our preparations. The Atlantic Rowing Race is more about the mind than just rowing. Ben had done the tough Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and lived on a deserted island. But he couldn't row. I was surprised by how little he knew about rowing, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I could have been more patient, but I needed to be honest about the improvements he needed. I should have known his level when I agreed to race with him.

Text: 'Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I was feeling restless. I dreamed of Arctic landscapes, cold and empty spaces, maybe because of the noise and crowds in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to hire me as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, they take tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow (for anything from an hour to five days). They started with six dogs, which quickly grew to more than 100. Recently, they took over a second place – the 'wilderness farm’, which they said was a beautiful but simple place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months if I knew what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical.’ I started packing right away. November 6, London On my flight, I look at a page with more than 100 pictures of huskies; I am supposed to memorize their names before I arrive, but I feel distracted and nervous. I put the page down and look out of the window instead. It is said that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, like a wave of opening flowers and leaves. But I think I am seeing the opposite, with winter moving south, and the rivers freezing. November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus north is everything I hoped for. We drive through endless dark forest – thin trees covered in snow – stopping sometimes to let reindeer move out of the way. I arrive at the farm after dark and am barely through the door when I’m given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. 'Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?’ Anna asks. It’s a rhetorical question. I follow the sound of barking, which becomes very loud by the time I reach the dog sheds. Three people are running back and forth with the huskies, harnessing them to sleds. The dogs are almost crazy with excitement, pulling hard against the ropes to start running. I can barely hear to introduce myself, but the others are too busy to talk much anyway. I stand on the side and rub the forehead of one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestures at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fall into the nearest sled. A command is given, and with a jerk, we are off into the dark, with only a head torch for light. November 15, Hetta It doesn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but not before a tough questioning about what I bring to the group. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asks. I’m unsure. Am I? More questions show that no, I am not: I have never driven a snowmobile, haven’t done woodwork since school, and have never chopped anything with an axe. 'You do have a driving licence?’ someone asks finally. I nod, relieved. The basics of dog-sledding can be learned quickly: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, whatever happens, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seems very complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs become very difficult in freezing conditions. A bowl of water will freeze solid while you watch, so we must make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head is spinning with instructions and my muscles ache from dragging heavy sleds – and from being dragged around by overexcited huskies. But I feel triumphant. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I email friends. 'In the snow.’'

On that day, as Radcliffe crossed the finish line, the press gathered to understand her amazing run. Her time was so good that it would qualify her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists asked her about a natural treatment, emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had recommended. Radcliffe used it to heal after she had an accident with a bike while training. Radcliffe says the achievement never really felt real to her. Looking back, she realizes it was a big deal at the time. However, she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day. Her team had decided not to set any limits, and that was their motto: no limits. During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. With him was Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried if she could keep up the fast pace, fearing she might drop out. Hartmann was angry at this, but he admitted that anyone who didn’t know how fit she was might think it was risky to start so fast. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe realized she could finish in under 2 hours 16 minutes if she crossed the line in less than three minutes. She had run 41 kilometers very fast but still managed to sprint the last part in 2 minutes 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, ‘I can run quicker than that,’ and even planned to do it again next year. Unfortunately, that didn’t happen. After the race, people wondered how an athlete with such an awkward style could beat the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with Radcliffe for weeks, helping her manage the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, ‘I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could handle pain like her. She would push me to work so deeply into her muscles that I had to ice my thumbs afterward.’ Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, ‘Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting.’ There was no time for a friendly greeting. Radcliffe was ready for a two-hour session. Hartmann said, ‘Paula would get every last bit of effort out of you. That's what made her so good.’ During that time, Hartmann spent so much time with Radcliffe that his other athletes became resentful. Can Radcliffe explain why no one has broken her record? ‘Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought Mary Keitany might do it. Maybe it's because people are racing each other more than racing themselves.’ What does she mean? ‘That mental way of never easing up, even when you've won the race, probably pushed me to it because I never thought, “I can relax now,” it was always: “keep pushing as hard as you can.” Radcliffe didn’t know it then, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She would never run as fast again. However, she left a lasting legacy, inspiring many women to take up long-distance running.

Text: 'When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I didn't know how viewers and the press would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food 'revolution' in Britain. I believed our show added something new to this, but I was still worried: would people like a cooking style that included not just techniques but also history, nostalgia, and science? I watched the first episode with both joy and fear. I needn't have worried. The show's success led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project feels like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called 'Perfection', each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was often very physical, with travel and meeting new people. In Search of Total Perfection is the latest in the series, where you travel the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who makes the best-tasting golden pasta. These people have spent years chasing their own ideas of perfection. Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was difficult, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish was left out. 'Where's steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?' I could imagine people asking. But after long discussions, the TV team and I made a list that had something for everyone. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of perfection, based on emotions, memories, and surroundings. Despite the book's title, I knew from the start that I wouldn't claim the recipes were 'definitive'. But I thought that by using my skills and knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could find out what made these dishes special. The dictionary says 'perfection' means being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation. Trying ideas and changing them until you have something unique. The TV series let me explore foods, people, and places I hadn't seen before, and I was excited about that. Searching for the best ingredients took me around the world. Some of my adventures included being taken to a canning factory that processed the wrong type of tomato and visiting a dairy farm with low standards, so we had to stop filming there! While refining each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow and using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken breasts in a hospital scanning machine, and nearly burning my house down trying to get the oven hot enough for a proper Neapolitan-style pizza.'

We were still hours away from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise and went off the road into a field, stopping suddenly. John got out and opened the hood. He looked at the engine for a long time with his hands in his pockets, looking like he knew what he was doing. ‘Actually, I don’t know what I’m doing,’ he said after a while, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, ‘We can’t stay here forever,’ she said. The field was big, with just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. ‘No, we can’t stay here forever,’ I repeated, because it was always safest to agree with Bea. We both got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We sat by the road and watched John get smaller as he went to find someone who knew about cars. Mum lay on the grass. ‘Tell us a story,’ she said. Bea lay down next to her. ‘Go on, tell us a story.’ So I told them about how, the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I told them what the birds talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, and the weather. I told them about the argument they had over a worm. ‘That’s silly, no one understands bird language,’ Bea said. My eyes stung. ‘I do.’ But my voice didn’t sound convincing. ‘Liar.’ I blushed. How could I be lying if I remembered every word? The more I thought about it, the less sure I was. ‘Mum…?’ But she had fallen asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind and waved and smiled at her through the back door windows. We followed John into a café. It was not far from where our van was parked. ‘It’s a hotel,’ John whispered. ‘I think it might be expensive.’ ‘We’ll just have some tea,’ Mum said, and we sat in the shade of the terrace. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. ‘It’s like syrup in there,’ she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. ‘I suppose it’s a miracle it got us this far,’ he said when it started to get dark. Mum put blankets on the ground for us to sleep in the hotel garden. It was nice to sleep on ground that wasn’t moving. ‘I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,’ John said from the other side of Mum. Half an hour later we were in a truck watching our van being pulled by a rope with John driving it. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept wondering how we’d get home now that our van had to be towed everywhere. I thought it might be easier if we could take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was at the welcome party in the hotel ballroom, talking to two other pianists at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were not competing like her: one was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city, whose name was Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke English well enough to discuss the music they were playing and their travel plans. 

‘I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer,’ Lucy told them. It sounded impressive, but she didn't really want to go. She often did things she didn't want to, like concerts and competitions, which made her miss so much school that she wasn't officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she studied with tutors from the University of San Francisco. She hadn't even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists in her age group from around the world. Out of thousands of applicants, she was chosen. Her dad bought her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to celebrate, and her little brother Gus dreamed of being at the festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. Lucy hadn't applied herself; her mom had sent in the application and CD. ‘I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,’ her mom said. Lucy thought it was more like her mom didn't want her to say no. At that time, Lucy thought disagreeing was the worst thing to do, so she didn't try to back out.

The guy from Tokyo leaned forward. ‘Tanglewood?’ he asked. ‘Yeah,’ Lucy replied. ‘How old are you?’ ‘Fifteen.’ He exchanged a look with Liesel/Louisa, who said, ‘Wow.’ Lucy didn't mean to brag. It was hard to know when sharing her achievements was too much. ‘It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're trying...’ Liesel/Louisa excused herself to talk to someone else. Tokyo stayed. ‘Have you ever been to Japan?’ he asked. He had long, shaggy hair, like many musician guys, to show they were cool. ‘Once. When I was, like, eight,’ Lucy said. He started to reply when Lucy's grandfather appeared. ‘Lucy, let me introduce you to someone,’ he said, pulling her away. ‘And don't get too friendly with the competition.’ ‘They're not the competition,’ Lucy said. ‘Everyone is the competition,’ her grandfather replied.

Her grandfather took her around the room to meet important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, only hearing about half of what was said. In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather said, ‘You did well, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are.’ Lucy liked being somebody, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention. Being a concert pianist didn't make her special to the kids she used to go to school with. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't know or care that she could play a Rachmaninov allegro. But in places like this, she knew she mattered.

Text: "‘It’s not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world,’ said Dad. He’s hard to argue with, so I decided to see what experts say – and it’s quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of identity, and are learning important technical skills for the digital age. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says ‘social networking is a key part of modern childhood. Teenagers don’t just use media for tasks like buying tickets or checking emails like adults do – they live in it. It’s not good or bad – it’s how you use it that matters.’ How does our social networking compare with what our parents did at our age? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it’s like the modern version of hanging out at the youth club, as today’s parents did when they were younger, to share jokes and gossip: a kind of virtual youth club. It helps teenagers develop a sense of identity away from their parents and learn to deal with teenage issues and get along with their peers. Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says: ‘Adolescence is a time when you ask, who am I? Social networking can help you develop that self-identity: you can post about your favorite music or sports, discover what you enjoy, and see that other people have different views. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don’t use social media.’ He says that using social media can help if you’re shy: ‘Communicating online can be more comfortable than face-to-face, and there may be benefits from practicing social skills in a less threatening environment.’ Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He thinks they can help if you’re quiet and have a special interest because they let you connect with others who like the same things. ‘If you’re one of only three people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social networking group of people who like the same thing, you can still be popular, just in a different way,’ he says. Pauline White, a digital education expert, told me something interesting: ‘It’s people your age who find new interests online, join groups of like-minded people – and then create their own content – who are really using the potential of social networks.’ She thinks social networking is becoming a creative force: teenagers are making videos, podcasting, and blogging about things that interest them. Photo-sharing sites, she says, are changing creativity. Keen photographers can connect with each other, learn skills, share images, and deepen their interest. ‘This all adds to employability and will be useful in the workplace,’ she says. ‘Every business uses social media to sell and increase brand awareness – and you need to understand how it works and can create customers. For example, if you develop a product and have 1000 friends on different social networks, they’re all potential customers for that product. If you link all those networks together, there’s your customer base.’ Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and start working, agrees Matthews. ‘One of the great things about many sites is the chance to work with others to create content and then share it. Collaboration is a real 21st-century skill and an important part of being employable in a digital age.’"

Text: 'When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, a long trip through nine western states in the US and a Canadian province might not be the first idea. However, my parents had a different plan for our summer vacation this year. My dad decided to organize what many teenagers might consider a nightmare: a big family bonding trip. "Not enough people do this anymore," my parents said before the trip, while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, "There are probably good reasons why!" In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and clothes for all kinds of weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. With barely enough room left for us in the car, we started our "Family Great American Road Trip." As we left our comfortable home for smaller places to stay over the next five thousand miles, I wondered what we were getting into. We drove west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under very dark, starry skies, but only after almost being blown off the highway in a dust storm. We quickly learned that on the road, cattle have the right-of-way! The next day, we got up early and started driving again. I noticed a pattern forming. The desert turned into mountains. The days started to feel the same, but each adventure was unique. We walked in the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly tourist town gave us a hint of what we would experience later. As we climbed to our next destination, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best for Jeep drivers. Everywhere we stopped, we saw a mix of old and new. Dealing with construction traffic became normal. We laughed when we saw the big "CLOSED" signs at the Four Corners Monument. We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. "Bear jams," managed by park volunteers, were common when traffic stopped to let a bear cross. Our own close encounter with a bear on the road (and a worried park ranger) gave us unforgettable memories. As we continued, life back home seemed far away, and even the old hotel we stayed in, with its problems, didn’t ruin our excitement. It was a 95-year-old building with no internet or cell phone service, but it had the most amazing views. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we headed back south. My parents were right. You don’t need to go to a faraway place to find something special. It was both happy and sad to be home again, but at least I hadn’t argued with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos of our crazy journey to look through. I knew I would remember the unplanned and spontaneous moments the most.'

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy would finish her last year of school, living under the care of the college Head. It was important for Amy to stay because it was her final year. Amy was happy because she got the best room at the college, with a kitchen and study area. She also had free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would still watch over Amy, even if she didn't like it. So, Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. Rose only had vague holiday memories of her grandmother and never knew her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, Rose’s parents were not excited, but Daisy insisted it was no trouble and wanted to know her granddaughter again. Rose didn’t fully understand why her parents didn’t get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past. Rose was ten years old when she last saw her grandmother, but her memories were happy. Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and liked bringing people together. Rose expected dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips. This made Rose smile. Her grandmother was not a typical old lady and seemed to attend more social events than the Queen of England. Before moving, Dahlia and Rose talked. Rose was sensible and mature. She knew about healthy eating, exercise, and sleep. But Rose wanted independence. She wanted to play music loud, invite friends over, or go out without asking for permission every time. She didn’t want to be nagged about homework or staying out late. Daisy understood. Rose’s mother gave her a new touch-screen phone with a video camera for emergencies. Rose was very happy. They agreed it would be about trust. Daisy would trust Rose to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If there were problems, they would talk about it. Rose was never a wild child. Her school friends were similar, so her school reports and exam results were always good. This helped her. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and start her life again. It was her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. She knew this was the last time because she would start her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new beginning, a new piece in the puzzle of her life.

Charlotte Grainger says her primary school teacher was the first to suggest she might write a novel. "I thought writing a book was a big achievement because it seemed so difficult. I didn't know what other teenagers were doing, like being in the Olympics. When I turned 13, I thought: 'I might as well try this now.'" The novel Charlotte started then is about to be published. "I recently told my ex-teacher about it, and she was surprised. She said she thought I would do it when I was 30 or 40. That idea never occurred to me—I didn't see why I should wait to do something I might be good at."

It's a winter afternoon at Charlotte's publisher's office. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was still surprised to see a teenager there. The book is a big achievement: the story is confident and full of action. Nothing about it, except the age of its main character, suggests it was written by a teenager. The public relations person for the book is with us in case Charlotte needs help. But she doesn't need any support. She is independent, with a lively face and intelligence, but also a steadiness that stops her from being overconfident.

Charlotte knows the limits of her youth. I ask her about the complex moral issues she raises. "I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. There aren't many life lessons I can give my readers," she says, laughing. "I don't think my understanding of the world is limited by my age, but I don't think I'm very wise either. I was just interested in exploring the theme of taking responsibility."

She has a theory about teenagers and how they are "betrayed" by the fiction aimed at them. She says there are three types of teenagers in novels: "There's the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows nothing about the world, and the awkward teenager who isn't socially skilled." Reading about these types annoyed her. "What if you're basically fine? There aren't many stories about characters who aren't inadequate in some way. The impression teenagers can get from some writers is that they can't know who they are because they're not experienced enough. And when writers push this idea, it can hurt their self-belief."

Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy writers, some of whom you might think influenced her, but they almost discouraged her from writing. "Books by my favorite fantasy writers explore deep things about psychology and life. I asked myself: do I have to do this to write a good book, and can I really do it?" However, she praises a book called How Not to Write a Novel. "It tells you that if the reader starts to guess what's going to happen, the suspense is probably gone."

It would be easy to say that Charlotte's parents, both journalists, helped her get her novel published. Her father's connection with someone in publishing got her book read initially. She knows she was lucky because getting someone to read a first novel is hard, no matter the author's age. "Every aspiring writer needs support and a lucky break, but after that, you're on your own. Writers succeed or fail based on their talents, so I don't take things for granted," Charlotte concludes.

Text: "‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had some experience in freestyle ski-jumping, wanted to show he knew what he was doing. He went first, skiing down the slope towards the jump. He hit the ramp fast and flew up, arms flailing. Even we could see something was wrong. We held our breath. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly told us, ‘speed is unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle stuff. On past skiing holidays, I liked practising turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I didn’t know how to do it. If I’d tried to join the skateboarders, I’d have risked being laughed at. Then my parents decided we’d have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training centre in the US. It had a big indoor facility near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students jumped, tried new tricks, and landed in foam pits – not a realistic start for what was ahead on the slopes. After practising indoors, students went outside to try for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the centre’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – once you’re on the real jumps, if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat section behind the jump before the slope steepens again. Land in the zone and you keep moving forward, reducing impact. Land on the flat and you stop suddenly, which is painful. That’s why you need speed. At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore my brain and race towards the jump. My legs would almost go backwards as I neared the launch point, so I came down hard on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt shorter. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines in the centre. I thought I’d hate being indoors, looking at the snowy peaks outside, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some drills copied moves we’d make while ski-jumping, others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body was doing as you spun in the air. Gareth gave us feedback. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off, and then found myself lying in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more setbacks before I finally landed properly. Gareth seemed as happy as me, and for a few moments, I felt proud of achieving such a difficult goal. But that didn’t last long. On the final run of the day, I didn’t slow down as I approached the jump, became airborne, and landed correctly. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer on my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you grip the harness tightly. The ride stops for a moment, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs upwards. There is a pause, then a sudden drop, and you feel your stomach lift. You speed forward, turn sharply left, and go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you scream from deep inside. But you chose this: like millions of others each year, you paid to enter the theme park.

Amusement parks, with their exciting rides, are a big industry. To create the thrills and escape from reality that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers and designers working behind the scenes. Being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a child's dream job, but it is a real challenge. Designers must create the right mix of fun and fear while keeping passengers safe. They also need to add new features to keep visitors interested.

Many people think rollercoasters have become more intense over time, but most techniques used today were invented by John Miller, a US designer, in the early 20th century. Back then, rollercoasters were more extreme, but now designers are limited to the track designs from specialist manufacturers.

I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer', said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts, from the Royal Academy of Engineering, explained that it’s about quickly changing between different forces so people feel excited but safe. The goal is to make the ride thrilling without making people feel uncomfortable.

To create an amazing ride, teams must build a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, and combine it with new features like the tallest ride or the most twists. However, Professor Walker said that in the end, experience and trial-and-error are key. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed that designers need to understand what passengers want and test the rides themselves.

I asked if new technology, like virtual reality, will change rollercoaster design. Walker said not to expect big changes soon. Virtual reality can add something extra, but the physical rollercoaster experience will remain the main attraction for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already done a lot as a choreographer, creating dances for many theatres and dance companies. She also still dances sometimes. I wonder why she fits both activities into her busy schedule. ‘Dancing again reminds me of what it feels like to be in the studio taking orders from demanding choreographers, and how tense and frustrating that can be. Choreographers can forget what it’s like to rehearse all day long,’ she tells me. As a choreographer, she is like a teacher and enjoys working with young students. ‘A new dancer is often open to exploring new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they’re willing to take risks. They want success, but they don’t yet know their strengths and weaknesses well. This means they accept even harsh criticism. They might still question me sometimes, but I welcome their honest feedback.’ When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. ‘There may be music I don’t like, but I still make sure to create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a composer’s music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. That doesn’t mean starting over with new music. Ideally, I’d like to be more experimental and switch to different pieces – it’d help lift the mood when rehearsals get tough. But now I’m always working on big productions – the music is already written and can’t be changed.’ Miranda doesn’t want to stay with one institution. ‘I think it’s important to keep meeting new people. But I have to remember that all the theatres and schools I work with have different methods and styles. So I have to be ready to change the way I work each time I go somewhere new, instead of doing the same thing. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.’ We talk about a recent documentary on professional ballet dancers and choreographers. ‘There have been glamorous documentaries before that were misleading,’ says Miranda. ‘This one really tries to show viewers what life is like inside a dance company. There was one scene where a young dancer gets endless corrections, and I smiled when I saw it. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch but not made up for the cameras. The amount of work and dedication in ballet is underestimated by the public.’ I ask what makes a great ballet or dance production for Miranda. ‘It’s when everything the company has invested in – the music, the costumes, the lighting, and the dancers – all come together. Perfection may be too much to ask for, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and allows you to get away with a few wrong artistic choices. I’ve been in productions where the dance steps are great, but something about the costumes or props distracts. And that’s disappointing.’ Miranda has done so much work I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? ‘People want to put a label on you, and I don’t understand that. There’s also a trend to develop expertise in a narrow area. I don’t follow that, though the time may come when I’m happy to be known for one thing. For now, I just want to widen my horizons.’

Text: 'A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that you can see amazing things on TV, but why stay at home on your sofa when there’s so much to experience outside? That conversation gave me the idea for my unusual four-day trip and a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs. A friend of mine was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the star of the film. I attached three wheels and some cables to it and connected them to old seatbelts over my shoulders. I put my luggage on the seats and slept on the sofa each night, even one night on the beach. Several friends joined me along the way, helping to pull the sofa and encouraging me to keep going. I’ve been on several walking trips in recent years, but this was something completely new. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and it was on main roads, so I could stop at a roadside café and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of having the wind blow away my sandwiches while sitting on a rock. I got used to telling people, “No, I’m not doing it for charity, I’m not training for a marathon”. When someone at work asks me about my weekend, I’d rather explain how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England than talk about the latest show on TV. You’ll be able to see the film on my website.'

Text: 'When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I was excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually traveled with, was busy, so I decided a group holiday might be good for me. The man at the Greek port seemed curious when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained I wouldn't be alone for long; I’d be joining ten others to swim around the tiny islands. Although still puzzled, he showed me on board with a smile. Our group had exchanged emails before we started, but there was little time to chat before our first group swim. Our guides explained a support boat would be with us all the time, and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, then it was time for our first proper 1.5 km swim and I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool, and done some river swimming, but never long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger and I was at the back of the slow group - not where I’d hoped to be. I watched faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to complete this first distance, though, and was happy when I finally managed it on my own. The following days had a routine: jumping in; reaching a comfortable speed; stopping to admire the scenery. As the swims got longer, so did my speed and happiness at completing them. There seemed little need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come again next year.'

Text: 'Being a flight attendant is not easy. But since I started the job, I have traveled everywhere, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, I have a lot of free time, and life is never boring – which makes it a great job for a young person like me! As a child, I went to a boarding school in another country, away from my family, so I always flew alone when school started and ended. Feeling lonely, I would ask the flight attendants if I could help give out meals to passengers, and some of them let me. I remembered this later when I wanted to leave my banking job and look for something new. There were many young people at the interview, and many were accepted. They were often well-qualified like me and were changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say – more than just saying I loved to travel, as everyone else would say that too. Instead, I talked about my strengths and previous work experience – and I got the job! I would recommend this kind of work to anyone, as there are many things that make it worthwhile – but the free flights I get are not the most important. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying – ‘no-one’s finished till everyone’s finished.’ It’s like a big family – even though we don’t see each other all the time, we’re still close. When I’m not working, I don’t have to take work home. And if I do get difficult passengers, which is rare, I always know the flight will soon be over and I’ll probably never see them again!'

Text: 'At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy seeing the children succeed at things they never thought they could do. Almost all the children know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for most of them. Some children feel very nervous, but after some encouragement, they agree to try, and they all reach the top in the end. This makes them feel great. We do have children who miss home at the beginning of the week. It's not the really young ones who feel like that the most – it's actually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can phone home after lunch. Then when they ask again, usually after dinner, we say it's a bit late to phone now, do it tomorrow. Most children are fine in a couple of days, and at the end of their week's stay, they all come up to us and thank us because they have had a great time. It's not always the children who feel lonely. We do get parents who are on the phone all the time, asking how their child is doing, which is not necessary. Often their son or daughter will be busy, playing games or doing something else, so we have to tell the parents to call back another time. We often get a certain type of child coming, usually dressed in expensive new clothes. Children like this usually argue when we tell them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand the reason why.'

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after five years in the USA, where it was voted ‘Best Musical’ four times! Doing the show with an all-British cast was challenging. In the UK, there are more limits on how many performances young actors can do each week. In the USA, they can do more shows. Because of this, twice as many actors were needed in the UK. Luckily, the director found many talented UK-based actors, and they’ve just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. Although the theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, it’s been full every night. Everyone wants to hear the songs that first became popular in America. I met 11-year-old Jamie, one of the show’s actors. ‘It’s great that I get paid to play,’ he said, ‘especially a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He told me how busy the young actors are. ‘We have normal school lessons each day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ And what do they think of the show? ‘Well, my whole class came! The theatre has special deals on tickets for schools. They loved it and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. When I said I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played Days, a song I didn’t know. Jamie helped me, and I was happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s ability and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! While the young actors were already musicians, with some playing several instruments, none had played in a band before. Fortunately, they found it quite easy. Jamie admitted that the hard part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were concentrating so much that they forgot to smile! The show is on in London for another year and is well worth seeing.'
